title: If you own these funds, you are an investor in the major gunmakers
text: Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook If you own these funds, you are an investor in the major gunmakers Major funds invested in gun stocks include the Vanguard Total Stock Market ETF, iShares Russell 2000 ETF and Schwab U.S. Broad Market ETF. The gun stocks tend to comprise a very small fraction of the entire fund. Post to Facebook A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Veuer's Nick Cardona has that story. Buzz60 Smith and Wesson handguns are displayed during the 2015 NRA Annual Meeting & Exhibits on April 10, 2015 in Nashville, Tennessee. (Photo: Justin Sullivan, Getty Images) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Last week's mass killing of 17 people at a public high school in Parkland, Fla., has caused some major pension funds and institutions to investigate the extent of their investments in gun makers. Some of Wall Street's largest exchange-traded funds are currently invested in American Outdoor Brands — formerly Smith & Wesson — and Sturm, Ruger & Co. , designers, makers, and retailers of firearms for domestic buyers. Exchange-traded funds holding American Outdoor Brands and Sturm, Ruger & Co. Vanguard Total Stock Market ETF (VTI) iShares Russell 2000 ETF (IWM) Vanguard Small-Cap ETF (VB) iShares Core S&P Total U.S. Stock Market ETF (ITOT) Vanguard Total World Stock ETF (VT) Schwab U.S. Broad Market ETF (SCHB) iShares Russell 2000 Growth ETF (IWO) iShares Russell 3000 ETF (IWV) Schwab U.S. Small-Cap ETF (SCHA) iShares U.S. Aerospace & Defense ETF (ITA) Vanguard Extended Market ETF (VXF) Schwab Fundamental US Small Co. Index ETF (FNDA) Vanguard Consumer Discretionary ETF (VCR) PowerShares FTSE RAFI US 1500 Small-Mid Portfolio (PRFZ) SPDR Portfolio Total Stock Market ETF (SPTM) Source: FactSet Fierce scrutiny has pushed New Jersey state lawmakers to restrict the state's public pensions from investing in the stocks of gun manufacturers, while the world's largest asset manager, BlackRock, said it would "engage" with the companies on their response to the shooting. To be sure, while each fund in the list contains shares both of American Outdoor Brands and Sturm, Ruger & Co., the gun stocks tend to comprise a very small fraction of the entire fund, less than 1% of the entire portfolio. The funds on the list are largely "passive." That is, they are investors in the stocks because the shares are members in certain indexes tracking the economy. There isn't a manager making a conscious decision to buy the gunmakers for these funds, they are invested in the stocks because these companies are in the appropriate index mimicking a part of the U.S. economy. © CNBC is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news and commentary.
